text: Think step by step Act as an **English grammar checker designer"Now the target users are C1-lev ESL L1 Cantonese speakers, causal and professional contexts.You need a full, exhaustive list of errors + minimal pairs the checker must always identify, and then indicate in the list that each of them is an error that eithera. A checker must flag and explain,b. A checker must only flag Provide a list of types of errors + minimal pairs,DO NOT ANALYSIS Below is a structured list of error types relevant to C1 Cantonese L1 users, with minimal pairs.Each item: Type Minimal pair (incorrect → correct) Flagging: a) flag + explain, b) flag only 1. Subject–verb agreement (3rd person -s) He go to work every day. → He goes to work every day. She like coffee. → She likes coffee. Flagging: a 2. Subject–verb agreement (existential “there”) There is many reasons. → There are many reasons. There are a big problem. → There is a big problem. Flagging: a 3. Tense consistency in a clause Yesterday I go to Central. → Yesterday I went to Central. Last year we are very busy. → Last year we were very busy. Flagging: a 4. Present perfect vs past simple I have seen him yesterday. → I saw him yesterday. I saw him many times before. → I have seen him many times before. Flagging: a 5. Progressive vs simple aspect I am understanding the problem now. → I understand the problem now. She checks the report now. → She is checking the report now. Flagging: a 6. Misuse of future “will” vs “be going to” I will meet him at 3 (fixed plan). → I am going to meet him at 3. Look at the clouds, it is going to rain. → Look at the clouds, it will rain. Flagging: a 7. Modal verbs + bare infinitive He can to go now. → He can go now. You must to finish this. → You must finish this. Flagging: a 8. Redundant auxiliary “do” I don’t know where do they live. → I don’t know where they live. She asked why did he leave. → She asked why he left. Flagging: a 9. Question word order You are going where? → Where are you going? He is coming when? → When is he coming? Flagging: a 10. Negation with “no / not any” I have no time. → I don’t have any time. I don’t have no time. → I don’t have any time. Flagging: a 11. Double negatives I don’t need no help. → I don’t need any help. She never says nothing. → She never says anything. Flagging: a 12. Article omission with singular count nouns He is manager of the team. → He is the manager of the team. I bought computer yesterday. → I bought a computer yesterday. Flagging: a 13. Unnecessary article with plural / uncountable The happiness is important. → Happiness is important. The informations are useful. → The information is useful. Flagging: a 14. “The” with generic vs specific The dogs are friendly animals. → Dogs are friendly animals. Dogs in the next flat are noisy. → The dogs in the next flat are noisy. Flagging: a 15. Countable vs uncountable nouns Many informations. → Much information. Much furnitures. → Much furniture. Flagging: a 16. Singular vs plural noun forms These equipment are new. → This equipment is new. This data is wrong. → These data are wrong. Flagging: a 17. Mass/count alternation (contextual) I drank two coffees. → I drank two cups of coffee. We ordered three chickens. → We ordered three roast chickens. Flagging: b (style-sensitive) 18. Prepositions of time I will see you in Friday. → I will see you on Friday. He left on 2010. → He left in 2010. Flagging: a 19. Prepositions of place He is waiting in the bus stop. → He is waiting at the bus stop. She arrived to the office. → She arrived at the office. Flagging: a 20. Prepositions after verbs Listen music. → Listen to music. Discuss about the issue. → Discuss the issue. Flagging: a 21. Prepositions in fixed phrases Depend of him. → Depend on him. Responsible of the project. → Responsible for the project. Flagging: a 22. Overuse of “in Hong Kong people say…” In Hong Kong people will say… → In Hong Kong people say… In Hong Kong we are calling it… → In Hong Kong we call it… Flagging: b 23. Wrong comparative/superlative forms He is more tall than me. → He is taller than me. This is the most funniest thing. → This is the funniest thing. Flagging: a 24. Missing “than” in comparatives He is taller me. → He is taller than me. This is more important you think. → This is more important than you think. Flagging: a 25. Double comparative More better solution. → A better solution. More earlier meeting. → An earlier meeting. Flagging: a 26. Adjective vs adverb She speaks good. → She speaks well. He did bad in the exam. → He did badly in the exam. Flagging: a 27. Position of adverbs He drinks coffee always. → He always drinks coffee. She goes usually to work at 9. → She usually goes to work at 9. Flagging: a 28. Misuse of “very” vs “too” It is too good. → It is very good. The room is very small to live in. → The room is too small to live in. Flagging: a 29. Word order in noun phrases My three this friends. → These three friends of mine. The Hong Kong beautiful city. → The beautiful city of Hong Kong. Flagging: b 30. Word order with indirect objects I explained him the problem. → I explained the problem to him. She suggested me a solution. → She suggested a solution to me. Flagging: a 31. Missing subject pronoun (spoken transfer) Is very difficult. → It is very difficult. Don’t know what to do. → I don’t know what to do. Flagging: a 32. Omission of “it” in clefts / weather Is raining. → It is raining. Is important to try. → It is important to try. Flagging: a 33. Dummy “it” vs “this/that” This is no need. → There is no need. Is no need to hurry. → There is no need to hurry. Flagging: a 34. Relative clause omission The man lives upstairs is my boss. → The man who lives upstairs is my boss. The company I work is big. → The company I work for is big. Flagging: a 35. Wrong relative pronoun The person which called me. → The person who called me. The company who hired me. → The company that hired me. Flagging: a 36. Relative pronoun redundancy The man who I met him yesterday. → The man who I met yesterday. The place where we went there. → The place where we went. Flagging: a 37. Gerund vs infinitive after verbs I suggest to go home. → I suggest going home. I decided going home. → I decided to go home. Flagging: a 38. Gerund as subject To smoke is bad for health. → Smoking is bad for your health. To read helps you relax. → Reading helps you relax. Flagging: b 39. Parallel structure errors He likes reading, to swim and jogging. → He likes reading, swimming and jogging. The job is challenging, demanding and it is rewarding. → The job is challenging, demanding and rewarding. Flagging: a 40. Run-on sentences / comma splices I was tired, I went home. → I was tired, so I went home. She is smart, she can finish it. → She is smart, and she can finish it. Flagging: a 41. Fragment sentences Because I was tired. → I went home because I was tired. Which caused a lot of problems. → This caused a lot of problems. Flagging: a 42. Overuse / misuse of “and so on” We need pens, paper, stapler and so on. → We need stationery such as pens, paper and a stapler. Many people, cars, shops and so on. → Many people, cars and shops. Flagging: b 43. Misuse of “etc.” We sell phone, computer, TV etc. → We sell phones, computers and TVs. We help with design, planning, development etc. → We help with design, planning and development. Flagging: b 44. Capitalization of proper nouns I work in hong kong university. → I work in Hong Kong University. He is from mainland china. → He is from Mainland China. Flagging: a 45. Capitalization of “i” i think it’s fine. → I think it’s fine. Can i ask a question? → Can I ask a question? Flagging: a 46. Punctuation with lists We need: apples oranges bananas. → We need apples, oranges and bananas. The report is clear, concise, accurate. → The report is clear, concise and accurate. Flagging: a 47. Commas in complex sentences If we finish early we can leave. → If we finish early, we can leave. When I arrived, then we started. → When I arrived, we started. Flagging: a 48. Missing period at sentence end Please send me the file** ASAP** → Please send me the file ASAP. I look forward to your reply** Thank you** → I look forward to your reply. Thank you. Flagging: a 49. Overuse of exclamation marks (professional) Please send the report by 5pm! → Please send the report by 5pm. I will attend the meeting! → I will attend the meeting. Flagging: b 50. Apostrophes in possessives This is Jacks car. → This is Jack’s car. The companies policy is strict. → The company’s policy is strict. Flagging: a 51. Its vs it’s It’s color is red. → Its color is red. I think its going to rain. → I think it’s going to rain. Flagging: a 52. Plural vs possessive “s” All the student’s must attend. → All the students must attend. The employees performance is good. → The employees’ performance is good. Flagging: a 53. Contractions in formal writing We don’t have enough data. → We do not have enough data. We can’t confirm this yet. → We cannot confirm this yet. Flagging: b (context-dependent) 54. Over-formal double subjects Our company, we believe in quality. → Our company believes in quality. My friend, he is a lawyer. → My friend is a lawyer. Flagging: a 55. Overuse of passive in casual writing The report was written by me yesterday. → I wrote the report yesterday. The email was sent by us. → We sent the email. Flagging: b 56. Missing passive form The report need finish today. → The report needs to be finished today. The form need sign. → The form needs to be signed. Flagging: a 57. “Very” with non-gradable adjectives Very perfect. → Absolutely perfect. Very impossible. → Almost impossible. Flagging: a 58. “So” vs “such” It was such difficult. → It was so difficult. It was so a big problem. → It was such a big problem. Flagging: a 59. “Much / many / a lot of” I have much friends. → I have many friends. I don’t have many money. → I don’t have much money. Flagging: a 60. “Some / any / no” Do you have some question? → Do you have any questions? I don’t have some idea. → I don’t have any idea. Flagging: a 61. “Another / other / the other” I have another two questions. → I have two other questions. Please send me other file. → Please send me another file. Flagging: a 62. “Each / every / all” Each people must sign. → Every person must sign. Every of them agreed. → All of them agreed. Flagging: a 63. “Few / a few; little / a little” We have few time, we can relax. → We have a little time, we can relax. I have a few money. → I have a little money. Flagging: a 64. Pronoun reference ambiguity When John spoke to Peter, he was angry. → When John spoke to Peter, John was angry. The company told the staff they must move. → The company told the staff that the staff must move. Flagging: b 65. Gender-neutral pronouns in professional context Every employee must submit his report. → Every employee must submit their report. Each student must bring his laptop. → Each student must bring their laptop. Flagging: b 66. “Who / whom” Whom is calling? → Who is calling? The person who I spoke to. → The person whom I spoke to. Flagging: b 67. “Me / I” in coordination Me and my friend went. → My friend and I went. She gave it to John and I. → She gave it to John and me. Flagging: a 68. “Between you and I / me” Between you and I. → Between you and me. This is a secret between he and I. → …between him and me. Flagging: a 69. Direct vs indirect questions (word order) Can you tell me where is the station? → Can you tell me where the station is? I don’t know what does he want. → I don’t know what he wants. Flagging: a 70. Reported speech tense backshift (when required) He said he is busy. → He said he was busy. She told me she will come. → She told me she would come. Flagging: a 71. “Say / tell / ask” He told that he was tired. → He said that he was tired. She said me the answer. → She told me the answer. Flagging: a 72. “Do / make” Do a decision. → Make a decision. Make the homework. → Do the homework. Flagging: a 73. “Borrow / lend” Can you borrow me some money? → Can you lend me some money? I lent some money from him. → I borrowed some money from him. Flagging: a 74. “Say / speak / talk / tell” He talked me the news. → He told me the news. I want to say with you. → I want to talk with you. Flagging: a 75. “Hear / listen” I can’t listen you. → I can’t hear you. Did you hear to the music? → Did you listen to the music? Flagging: a 76. “Look / see / watch” I watch a bird in the tree. → I see a bird in the tree. I see TV every night. → I watch TV every night. Flagging: a 77. False friends: “actually / eventually” Actually we will finish next year. → Eventually we will finish next year. Eventually, I don’t like it. → Actually, I don’t like it. Flagging: a 78. False friends: “sensible / sensitive” He is very sensible to criticism. → He is very sensitive to criticism. That is a very sensitive plan. → That is a very sensible plan. Flagging: a 79. False friends: “economic / economical” This is an economic car. → This is an economical car. We face economical problems. → We face economic problems. Flagging: a 80. Collocation errors (business) Open the meeting. → Start the meeting. Do a presentation. → Give a presentation. Flagging: b 81. Register mismatch (too casual in formal email) Thanks a lot for your help! → Thank you very much for your help. Hey guys, please find attached… → Dear all, please find attached… Flagging: b 82. Over-politeness / redundancy in formal email Please kindly help to check. → Please check. Please be informed that… → (Often) Please note that… Flagging: b 83. Direct translation “I very like” I very like it. → I like it very much. I quite hate this. → I really hate this. Flagging: a 84. Direct translation “got / have” Our company got many projects. → Our company has many projects. Today got meeting. → There is a meeting today. Flagging: a 85. Direct translation “add oil” etc. Add oil! → Keep it up! / Hang in there! Add oil in the exam! → Good luck in the exam! Flagging: b 86. Redundant “also” / “too” I also agree too. → I also agree. / I agree too. He is also my colleague too. → He is also my colleague. Flagging: a 87. Misplaced “only” I only spoke to him yesterday. → I spoke only to him yesterday. I spoke to only him yesterday. → I only spoke to him yesterday. Flagging: b 88. “Because / so” double marker Because it rained, so we stayed home. → Because it rained, we stayed home. So we were late because the bus broke down. → We were late because the bus broke down. Flagging: a 89. “Although / but” double marker Although it was late, but we continued. → Although it was late, we continued. Even though he was tired, but he worked. → Even though he was tired, he worked. Flagging: a 90. “Very much / so much” I like it so much. → I like it very much. Thank you very much indeed. → Thank you very much. Flagging: b 91. Overuse of “very” (advanced style) It is very very important. → It is extremely important. She is very nice and very friendly. → She is extremely nice and friendly. Flagging: b 92. Overusing “and” instead of subordination I was tired and I went home early. → Because I was tired, I went home early. He was sick and he didn’t come. → Since he was sick, he didn’t come. Flagging: b 93. Using “but” instead of “and” The result is good, but we are happy. → The result is good, and we are happy. The plan is simple, but effective. → The plan is simple and effective. Flagging: b 94. “So that / in order to” I studied hard so that pass the exam. → I studied hard so that I could pass the exam. I studied hard for pass the exam. → I studied hard in order to pass the exam. Flagging: a 95. Infinitive of purpose vs “for + -ing” I went there for buy a book. → I went there to buy a book. I use this to doing homework. → I use this to do homework. Flagging: a 96. “Used to / be used to” I am used to eat late. → I am used to eating late. I used to eating late. → I used to eat late. Flagging: a 97. Conditional forms (1st, 2nd, 3rd) If it will rain, we will stay home. → If it rains, we will stay home. If I knew, I will tell you. → If I knew, I would tell you. Flagging: a 98. Mixed conditionals If I studied harder, I would have a better job now. → If I had studied harder, I would have a better job now. If I had more time, I would have finished it yesterday. → If I had had more time, I would have finished it yesterday. Flagging: a 99. “Unless” vs “if…not” Unless you don’t hurry, you’ll be late. → Unless you hurry, you’ll be late. Unless we aren’t careful, we will lose. → Unless we are careful, we will lose. Flagging: a 100. “Whether / if” I don’t know if or not he will come. → I don’t know whether he will come. Please let me know whether or not is he coming. → Please let me know whether he is coming or not. Flagging: b If you want, I can next convert this into a checklist/spec for implementation (error IDs, examples, and explanations) tailored separately for casual vs professional contexts.
